Intro.text:
This page is for
adult
patients. For pediatric patients, see:
radial head fracture (peds)
.

Background.text:
Most common fractures of the elbow, approximately 20% of elbow fractures
Caused by FOOSH in pronation leading to radial head being driven into the capitellum

Associated_injuries_(are_common).text:
Capitellum fracture
Olecranon fracture
Coronoid fracture
MCL injury
Elbow dislocation
DRUJ (distal radial ulnar joint) injury
Interosseous membrane disruption
Essex-Lopresti fracture
(radial head fracture, DRUJ, interosseous membrane disruption), requires ORIF
Terrible triad (radial head fracture, coronoid fracture,
elbow dislocation
)

Clinical_Features.text:
Pain in the lateral elbow, especially with pronation/supination of forearm
Swelling laterally and tenderness of radial head

Workup.text:
Elbow PA & lateral
Consider x-rays of humerus, forearm, and wrist (e.g. to rule out a
Essex-Lopresti fracture
)
Consider Greenspan (radial head-capitellum) view X-Ray
Lateral elbow is shot at 45 degrees to pick up subtle fractures

Diagnosis.text:
Ensure there is no tenderness over the rest of the forearm/wrist, to rule out an
Essex-Lopresti fracture
Typically diagnosed on
elbow X-ray
(
fractures are often subtle
)
Look for abnormal fat pad
Look for radiocapitellar line disruption

General_Fracture_Management.text:
Acute pain management
Open fractures
require immediate IV antibiotics and urgent surgical washout
Neurovascular compromise from fracture requires emergent reduction and/or orthopedic intervention
Consider risk for
compartment syndrome
Ice, elevation

Modified_Mason_Type.text:
Managment is often based on the Modified Mason classifications
[1]
Type I
- Nondisplaced or minimally displaced (<2mm) with supination and pronation intact or only limited by pain but not due to fracture
Immobilization with posterior long arm splint and sling in flexion and non-operative
Type II
- Displaced >2mm or angulated, possible mechanical limitation to forearm rotation due to the fracture fragment
Immobilization with posterior long arm splint and sling in flexion and operative follow-up for ORIF
Type III
- Comminuted and displaced causing mechanical disruption to rotational motion
Immobilization with posterior long arm splint and sling in flexion and operative follow-up for ORIF
Type IV
-Radial head fracture with associated elbow dislocation
Urgent coordination for ORIF or radial head arthroplasty due to need for annular ligamentous repair

Immobilization.text:
Sling immobilization in flexion
Nondisplaced fracture with no mobility restrictions: ortho follow up within 1wk
Displaced fracture or mobility restrictions: ortho follow up within 24hr
